moves.1. e4 c6 2. g3: This is really odd.  I like playing the caro kann because it is really solid and actually affords black a lot of aggressive attacking positions (contrary to popular belief).  Normally when I see some try to play anything but the actual main lines I generally assume they aren't very prepared to face the CK!
moves.2... d5 3. Bg2 dxe4: All too happy to exchange the pawn and get my knight out with tempo.
moves.4. Bxe4 Nf6 5. Bg2 Bg4: I like this better than Bf4.  I am trying to lure Nf3 as whites knight on f3 is almost always better than my LSB in a lot of Caro Kann positions.
moves.6. f3: This is a bad move.  It unnecessarily opens up white's king side.
moves.6... Bh5 7. Ne2: I think Nh3 might have been better.  Either way the pawn on f3 is not promising for white.
moves.7... e6 8. O-O Bg6: I am taking time with development as white's handling of the opening is completely passive and non-threatening.
moves.9. Kh1: Probably because he didn't want to see any checks on the g1-a7 diagonal.
moves.9... h6: To prevent any uncomfortable Nf4 or pawn bum rushes on my LSB.
moves.10. Nbc3: I really don't like this move.  I'm sure it's ok but white is basically showing that he doesn't care about establishing a pawn center in the middle of the board.
moves.10... Bd6 11. d3: Planning to put a knight on e4.
moves.12. Nf4 Bh7 13. Be3 O-O: Development completed.  Let's start the party!
moves.14. Bh3: Not really sure what the point of this is.  I think since white can't initiate a pawn break at all he is looking for play with his pieces.  Though there really is nothing for him to attack yet.
moves.15. Qc1: Again, no idea what white is doing.
moves.15... Qc7 16. Ne4: This looks like a solid move.  That square should be occupied by a knight.
moves.18. Ne2 Nd5: I like this move.  I am preparing f7-f5.  White can't challenge my knight with c4 as the d3 pawn would become extremely weak.
moves.19. Bf2 Rad8: Putting the other rook on the half-open d-file.
moves.20. a3: White was probably considering c4 but didn't want ...Nb4 as a response.
moves.20... f5: Claiming more space on the king side and getting ready for Nd5-f6 in case of c4.
moves.23... e4: Initiating the pawn break.  White's king is pretty much completely exposed.
moves.24. dxe4 fxe4 25. f4: White attempts to keep his king side somewhat secure at the expense of black gaining an extremely strong passed pawn. Aron would be so proud!
moves.25... Qd5: The beginning of a tactical onslaught.  This obviously threatens a discovered check however I am planning on bringing the queen over to the h file.
moves.26. Bg2 Qh5: This creates a number of uncomfortable problems for white.
moves.27. Re3: White has to prepare for black to play Ng4.  I think he should have played something like Bg1.
moves.28. Qg1: Again, white could have played Bg1 here, (unless I'm missing something).  This is playable though uncomfortable for white as all of his pieces are tied to defense.
moves.28... Rd2: Now threatening Nxf2.  Here white should have played Be1.
moves.29. Rf1: Instead he plays Rf1.  This is a tactical oversight.
moves.29... Rxf2 30. Rxf2: In order not to lose the queen white leaves the Rook on e3 hanging.
moves.30... Nxe3 31. Re2: White loses his mind and the game.
